testimony: Thank you Mr Zuma.  If he might just be sworn in please Mr Chairman.
You have to press the button on your mike when speaking.
Thank you Mr Chairman.  Mr Zuma, is it correct that you hail from the Richmond area and that you also stayed there during June 1991?
In what area did you specifically stay in Richmond during 1991?
I don't remember well, I would say I was about twenty four or twenty five.
Where you a member of the IFP at that stage?

Is it correct that you were brought up in the traditional Zulu way - that means that you believed in a traditional Zulu values and that you further believed in the culture in a sense of your forefathers and muti and so forth?
Why did you leave the school at standard five?
Because we were many children  at school, attending school at home  and my mother couldn't afford to send us to school.
Were your parents, were they also IFP supporters?
You have listened to all the evidence that was given by your co-applicant in this matter, can you tell this Commission in your own words, what happened on the 23rd of June 1991.

It was on the 23rd of June 1991 - ANC members attacked our place. As a person who was standing about the place, I could soon have a feeling and I had my whistle which we had to blow when we got attacked.
I will just ask you to go a little bit slower so we can write down what you say so just give a pause after each sentence please.

As I was staying on the high area I could see them coming, they were shouting.  I knew most of them because I grew up with them and we used to pass their place.  They were shouting at me saying Vusi we were coming there therefore I had to blow the whistle because I knew they were coming in and they were armed and there were many.  I told the other young boys to blow the whistles and we blew the whistles.
	I started running downhill because I was afraid I was going to be injured.  They came downhill and they started shooting towards our direction.  We started running downwards and we happened to assemble and we became many in numbers.  They shot one person Behkani Mkune if I remember well, yes it was Behkani Mkune.  After shooting at us they started running because that's how they used to do, they used to attack and run away.  
	After their retreat we sat down and tried to discuss as to what we're going to do.  We couldn't come at the same time so this is what we have to do, however one of our colleagues came out and said we should go and pay revenge.  
	After some time, at about half past five - as the area is a very strange area we have to go via the river and pass through passages and we knew it would take time -  we sit down and discussed this is how we're going to do it. One of a ...(intervention)
Just be a little bit slower in your evidence, you're going very, very fast.  Please go a little bit slower.

Bangi instructed us that or suggested that we should fight back and we all agreed with him.  We used to be armed in most cases.  We waited for some time and at about 5, because it looked as if it was going to rain and it was winter, we decided to cross and go towards their direction  Tabudeni.
	When we arrived at Tabudeni at the grounds we sat there because we knew that most people who were staying in that particular place - because most of the people who were staying next to area on the downhill have already vacated the place and they were running away.  We were about seventeen.   While we were still hiding somewhere there, one boy from the Dlamini family came out of the house - we could see because there was some moonlight and we could see that there was someone standing there and we started running towards that Dlamini place and we surrounded the house.  The boy ran away after one shot was fired.  
	I was thinking that the house was used as a camp because I heard some gunshots and people with me were shooting, myself I was holding a spear and some bolts.  I didn't manage to get into the house.  We were all competing to get in an attack.  When others got in I heard some women shouting from within the house and I got so afraid when I discovered that there were women inside the house.  I never intended to attack women.
	After these people were injured we continued with our journey.  We continued - I thought we attacked women and men or men only but when arrived in court I found that we also attacked women.  We went to another family which I couldn't identify - we found three young boys in the house.  We attacked and stabbed them in the house, we stabbed them.  
	I went outside and saw it through the window because some didn't die instantly - we wanted to kill them because we knew that these were the people who were attacking us.  Others might have ran away after hearing some gun sounds below.  After killing these three we passed to another family and we find women, there was a woman and her children.  I told the other comrades that they shouldn't kill the women because they've already killed some and I was warning them that they shouldn't kill them and therefore we have to leave the women in that particular house so we divided and the others had to go via another bush and we took the other way.
	We happened to meet the women who were running away.  After seeing us they started running.  I was in front and I heard the women crying.  It looks as if they were attacked.  I had to run back and go back and tell them that they mustn't attack them because it looked as though those were the people who passed and decided not to attack.  That's where one child was attacked.
	I told them that they shouldn't kill the women and the children because the people who we were targeting were ANC young men, whom we intended to go and attack.  We're not killing women, we're killing young men.  I intended to kill these ANC young men, members because those were the people who were attacking us.  	
	We took the young child to another family.  I don't know to whom the family belonged but we left the child there and we continued to a place called Ndaleni.  We arrived at ...(inaudible) Sadam.  We were going by to check whether there were some other IFP members.  Sadam told me that we should go up to Kwambonga's  place as maybe the people might be meeting there.
	They said Kwambonga, I didn't know the place so we continued, we went to some ...(inaudible) and we surrounded the house.  When we listened through the windows, we could hear some people inside who were laughing.  I suspected that they were happy because they think they have attacked us and killed us.  We started to - we hit the door  - there was a ..(indistinct) in the door and we used it to hack the door.  The door opened and we shot at the people and we also stabbed them with the spears and the bolts - one of them died instantly next to the rondawel.  That was the person who had these multiple stab wounds because he was stabbed by most of the people.
	Some of the people died right inside the house, some managed to jump out through the windows and run away.  After that we thought we killed all of them.  After some time we left them and continued to Mtusi's place because we ran out of ammunition.  Mtusi was one of our IFP member at Ndalene and we went to him to ask for ammunition.  He gave us eight.
Mr Chairman, don't you want to ...(inaudible) to intervene at this time to take a break for lunch.

I thought of one thing Mr Chairman, the witness is busy with the story and it is a quite intricate following of what happened there and I would wish it to be possible that he could just finish with his ...(inaudible)
Mr Chairman, may I make this further request that the linguist must try to reduce the speed, we cannot cope.  If my learned friend can just take control of him please.
Thank you.  If you could just pause each now and then to try and give us chance to try understand what you are saying.  Go ahead.

We went to Mtusi's place, we got some ammunition and we went below to a place called Selasa.  When we arrived at Selasa there was one family with the light one - I didn't know to whom the family belonged, we entered the family in groups.
Can you explain to us as to what kinds of ammunition you got from Mtusi?

As we were using the homemade guns and big guns, we got ammunition for 9mm and R1 ammunitions and R4 rifles ammunition.  We had different types of homemade guns.  One of the guns that we had was an AK47.

We went towards Lastla -  I knew a bit of the place, that's where we shot one old man.  I was just watching at the time, I didn't wish to be involved in attacking those people at that time, I don't know why it happened.  However, they shot that person and we, after that we left the place.  On our way we met two people and Gumbi shot them.  He shot at them because he thought they were coming to find out as to what's happening hearing the gunshots.  I don't know whether he killed them or not.
	We continued to a place called Matafeni.   When we arrived at Matafeni we entered at the first homestead, it was a new homestead.  We asked the mother in the house and she told us that she's coming from a particular place and we discovered that it was only the woman and there was nobody in the house, so we left to pass that family an we continued.
	I was insisting to them that they shouldn't kill women on our way because I intended that we should fight the ANC's young comrades.  However, most of the people with us they said, we have to kill all of them because we also lost our mothers in the war so whoever we find on the way, even the children, we have to kill them.
	I realised that there was nothing that I was going to do because if I continued to disagree with them, they were turn against me and kill me so I kept quiet and kept on watching all the incidents, whatever, all the things they were doing.  That's all I have to say.
No sound.

Mr Zuma, is there anything that you want to say to the victims and the families of the victims of that attack?  Maybe I'll repeat it, is there anything that you want to say to the victims and the families of the victims of the attack?
Yes, I would like to say something.

I would like to ask for forgiveness to those who lost their family relatives, especially to those whose children had been injured, those who's female relatives who were injured and also those who's male relatives were injured and I would like to ask them to forgive me, that's all.
Thank you Sir.  On this day when this incident took place, had a peace meeting between the IFP and ANC been arranged?
I don't remember and I never heard about such things.
So is this the first time that you've heard about that?
Yes, it was the first time after I was arrested.
To mount this attack, did you use any vehicles at all?
Did you see any vehicles while the attack was in progress?
I personally didn't see any car.  We had to pass streets but I didn't see any car.
Do you know that in the course of the attack, various items of furniture were stolen, stoves and big chairs and things like that?
I don't know anything and I didn't notice such things.

You didn't notice anybody carrying such large items of
furniture or equipment at all?
No, I didn't see any person.
When you launched the attack, did you try to disguise your appearance in any way by wearing balaclavas or any other type of disguise?
We had hats but not hats that covered our faces because we wanted them to see us when they happened to see us.

We've heard in Mr Gumbi's evidence that the attack on your area was mounted at about 3 o'clock or half past 3 and the whistles blew and you had a meeting and then you yourselves went on the attack somewhat later, 5.30/6 o'clock.  Do you know, do you personally know if any attempt was made to contact IFP leaders at all?
I don't understand this question as to where it's leading to - the involvement of IFP leaders, I don't understand that.
Well at the meeting which you had after your area had been attacked, they whistles has blown and you all met at a place, were there any of the local IFP leaders present there?
They were not there, it was only the youth and some elders.
The elders, who were the elders who were there?
I mean those who were older than us who were involved in the fight.
Did you make, did you or anybody else that you know of make any attempt to contact Paulas Vezi or your chief or anybody like that?

We didn't contact anybody.  The chief stayed at a far place and the headman was also a bit far so we couldn't contact them, we just took a decision after we were attacked that we have to attack back because we couldn't sleep as they were attacking us.
You say that the chief stayed at the far place, is that chief Majosi?
That's chief Dlamini who was staying at Pateni and chief Majosi at Ndaleni.
How far is your area from Pateni?
From where?  Can you repeat the question?
Koweni where you lived to Pateni?
It's a short distance but I can't estimate the exact distance, its a short distance but you have to walk to reach the place.
But chief Dlamini was there, why didn't you contact him?
We were confused.  Since they were attacking us we knew that we're going to sleep therefore we decided to fight back and hit back while everything was still hot.
And others  - Mr Vezi also live at Pateni?
Don't you think you should have contacted him as well?
We couldn't contact Vezi because he was far away.
I thought you said a moment ago that it was a short distance from where you lived to Pateni.

They way I'm explaining I'll say, if you have to leave Koweni to Pateni you have to walk a long distance however, myself I'm a bit far away from Koweni itself so it would take a long time for me to leave Koweni to Pateni because people we're going - we're going to come back and attack the people if we have to first go to Pateni so we have to stay at home and protect families and the properties therefore I would say it's far away to go to Pateni.
If your IFP leaders were at Pateni surely you should have asked, sent somebody to get help from them to deal in this, with this crisis you had?

It wasn't easy because we didn't have much time to contact ANC leaders to talk to them because the fighting was continuous since from January.  We fought until June where we had to be arrested.  We didn't get a chance to sit down and contact maybe Babin and  Vezi to sit down and talk about this violence.
When you got to Ndaleni why didn't you go and see chief Majosi?
It was because we intended to attack the ANC members because they terrorized us.  They came to our place, shot us and burnt people ...(inaudible).
Did you recognise any of the people who shot you, shot at you?
I knew most of them especially those from Magoda.  Some of them are in prison now.  These were people who were shooting police and I knew that when we arrived they might injure us.

Rather than contact your chief for help, don't you think you should have sent a warning to your chiefs that you were going to attack the ANC that night and they better be ready to protect themselves against retaliation?
I think the chief wasn't going to allow us to go and attack.
Why?  Do you think the chief would have allowed you to be injured and maimed and killed by the ANC without giving you an alternative to such attacks?

I will put it clearly.  Chief Majosi was at Ndaleni and they also used to shoot or attack him, he didn't do anything.  ANC members were shooting at him.  I knew that he was not of the view that we should fight back, that's why I'm saying that he wasn't going to allow us to go back and attack these people.
What about the leader of the IFP in your area, was that his attitude too that you should not fight back?
Vezi was not going to allow us to because he was one of the persons who wasn't involved in conflicts.
I'm told there was a van driving about Ndaleni that night carting people, are you sure you didn't see one?
May you please repeat your question.
I'm told that that night when you made the attack there was a van driving around Ndaleni carrying people, didn't you see it?
I don't know anything about that and I didn't see the van.
The people you've mentioned as seeing at Ndaleni are now dead aren't they?  Mtusi, Ndoda Mtusi, he's dead isn't he?
Yes, I heard in 1991 or 1992 that he died and chief Majosi died.
And Ntolo also died, didn't he?
I don't know what happened to Ntolo, I last saw him in 1991 at Ndaleni.  I don't know where he went to.

No further questions.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR RATHMAN

Thank you Mr Chairman.  Mr Zuma, in your application and letter attached to the application - I'll refer member of the Committee to page 34, point 2 of the bundle - the translation of your letter.   I'm going to read from paragraph 3 thereof, which reads
Honourable members, I want to make it clear that nobody ordered me to attack the deceased but I was revenging the death of my brother.
Did you hear that?

Yes, I heard that my brother was injured but I don't think, I don't think I would have said that because the brother who got injured was injured after I was arrested.  I don't know because I didn't write the letter, it was written by Mrs Knobe.  My brother died after I was arrested, I don't know that, I deny that.
Are you saying you did not write the letter?
I can't say, I can't agree that I didn't say my brother passed away.
Did you write the letter?  Have you seen the letter we're talking about?
Yes, I made an application for amnesty.  Yes, I would say I did write this letter.  I accept the letter as written by me.

I think in fairness to you Mr Zuma, the translation is incorrect as it stands, if you pass.  You are saying and I quote
	The Honourable, I want to put it clear is that nobody sent me ... (in Zulu that means your brother was seriously injured -  it's an expression in Zulu).  I say that ...(inaudible)  It wasn't because someone died.  What you are trying to say here is that your brother was seriously sick, terminally ill.

I'll say that's it's a problem because since we are in prison we normally, I normally sometimes loose my mind so while I was writing maybe I didn't understand what I was writing.  As a prisoner something may have affected my mind, that's why at the moment I'm disagreeing with that.  When I gave the amnesty application forms, I knew that I'd be given a chance to speak.  My younger brother died after I was arrested therefore I will say that that may be the reason why I can't comprehend the situation very well.
What we're trying to explain is that when you used these words you didn't want to say that your brother had died at that time.
That's correct, I wanted to explain that my brother was injured and died after I was arrested.
At the time when you launched the attack, had anything happened to your brother?

Nothing happened to our home, our homestead was burnt and we couldn't stay there and that's all that happened when we were attacked.  Our family was at the outskirts and that was the first family on the border.
Mr Zuma to avoid further confusion, my question is so simple, at the time when you joined the force and attacked, had anything happened to your brother, the one you're referring to in the letter?
Now when you say ... no English translation  how can you say you revenge because your brother was injured when nothing had happened to him at the time you launched the attack?

As I've explained before, I was confused while writing the letter.  I did intend to say that he died because of the violence which continued in my place.  I'm trying to correct that because while we're in prison we normally don't see things very well or clear.
Now if that is the position, on whose behalf were you revenging when you launched this attack?

Many family members and neighbours were killed.  One of the girl mother died and some other family members were injured and they were attacking the Inkatha families therefore as an Inkatha we had to pay revenge because when those others were attacked and injured, I thought I could be injured at any time.
I thought I heard you say that the attack was not sanctioned or ordered or commanded by the IFP, did I hear you correctly?
Yes that's correct, we were not sent by the IFP.
Will I then be correct to state that when you went there to launch that attack, it had nothing to do with IFP as an organisation?

I won't agree with that because it was ...(inaudible) which organisations which we were fighting although I won't say I was, we were sent by IFP, I would say it was IFP and ANC people who were fighting.

Mr Zuma - I'm sorry Mr Mpshe- I'm a little perturbed by the evidence.  I keep on listening from Mr Gumbi and now from yourself that you - the IFP leadership did not know anything about the attacks which were happening in Richmond.  We've already heard evidence from Mr Gumbi and you have now also testified thereto that there were repeated incidents of attack in Richmond.

I mean the fighting between the ANC and the IFP was the order of the day.  You must I presume have held several meetings as IFP members together with your leadership to discuss about this very serious issue of the attacks which were going on between the two political parties.  Now are you saying that there wasn't even a suggestion from the leadership about what you as followers were to do in the event of an attack by ANC supporters, is that what you want us to believe?  Truly Mr Zuma, we merely want to understand the causes of the fighting that were going on in Richmond and in this case we are trying to understand what prompted you to do what you did, we are interested in knowing the truth.

I would say that none of the IFP leaders sent us to go and attack the ANC members, we attacked them because they didn't want Inkatha at Richmond, that's what I'll put clearly before the Committee.  We attacked them because they didn't want us, they wanted ANC to be the only ruling party in that area.  I wasn't sent by any chief or any senior member at Richmond, we just went there to attack the ANC people who attacked us.
Mr Zuma, you testified that you could see the people who were attacking you and you knew most of them, do you remember that?
May you please repeat the question?
In your evidence you said you could see the people who attacked you and you knew most of them.
I can't understand the question very well.
He hasn't asked a question yet, he's just telling you what you said, just listen.
I would like you to please repeat for me what I said.

You said - I'll quote you now
I could see them - that is the attackers - I could see them come, I knew most of them - the them is the attackers.
Now of the people that you attacked, maimed and killed, are any of them some of those that you saw attack you?
I would say it was the ANC members from Ndaleni because one of the persons Dumisani Ntolo.  I saw him as a person whom I knew and I could recognise him.

Mr Zuma, please understand my question.  You saw these people - you knew most of them, now those that you attacked, are they amongst those that you saw attack you?  I don't want to know whether they were ANC, I just want to know whether those that you knew and you saw attack you, where those included as your victims?

Those whom we attacked as we also attacked women, I would say the women were not involved but the men were the people that attacked us.  I would say I personally think those were the people who attacked us.   I didn't see them because it was in the evening, I was seeing them from a distance.  When they started shooting I ran away.
You told us you saw and you recognised most of the people who attacked you, is that true or not?
I put it in this way,  I knew most members of the ANC in that area, not that I saw them, I knew them.
You now say you didn't recognise the people who attacked you.

I don't know the people that attacked us on that particular day but I said that I knew most of those people but I didn't see them on that specific day of the attack.  I knew the people who used to attack us.
So the statement, the evidence from yourself that - I could see them come, I knew them - is incorrect?

I saw them coming from the other attacks but I don't ...(inaudible) specific incidents of the last attack, I didn't recognise them because when they started shooting I ran away.  However I used to see them before, coming to attack.  I could see them that it was so and so coming.
So this evidence that you've just given and you said it's not right, it pertains to the incidents in the past not the incident on the day when you also decided to revenge, am I right?
Now let's restrict ourselves to the incident on that day, the 23rd of June.  These attackers, your attackers, did you see them?
Yes, I saw them but I couldn't recognise who they were.
Did you see someone Ndaseni Ntolo?
Dumisani Ntolo, didn't you see him at the time you were being attacked?
I didn't see Dumisani Ntolo, I saw him in court.
But you mentioned his name earlier as someone you saw amongst the attackers, why did you do that if it was not true?

I would say it's a mistake or confusion because that happened a long time ago, I don't remember well and I can't get the full picture because this happened in 1991 and I just remember some bits and pieces of what happened.

Mr Zuma I'm a little confused, maybe you can throw some light on my confusion.  You see when you started in your evidence you stated that you knew most of the people who had launched an attack in your stronghold because you grew up together.  This is what I have in my notes but further than that, in your application you stated the name of Dumisani Ntolo as the person that you knew ...(intervention)
As having ...(inaudible) on the day in question.
You didn't recognise Dumisani Ntolo as one of the attackers on the 23rd of June, is that what you are now saying?
And are you saying you didn't recognise any of the attackers on the 23rd of June?
I didn't recognise any however they came shooting but I couldn't recognise who they were.

You now want to amend your statement because I don't know how we actually have what you earlier on stated when you were led by your attorney in chief.  You said I knew most of the attackers because we grew up together in the same area, they were armed and many.

I think we should add a little on my note.  Before what you said which was just put to you, you were asked specifically about the 23rd of June and that's when you said - on the 23rd of June when you were attacked so we're not talking about the past or other things.  You were specifically asked by your own lawyer when you said on the 23rd of June when we were attacked, I knew most of them.
Why Mr Zuma, would you make such a mistake, are you saying it's a question of the interpreters?  How could you have made such a mistake, it is an important piece of your evidence?

Mistakes do happen.  As a convicted prisoner and I stayed a long time in jail, sometimes I get confused and I'm not able to give concise answers.  What I knew is that coming before the Committee, I was going to give the full account of what I know and did.  I didn't know that I would be asked so many questions and I would have to answer them.
	I get confused as you throw so many questions at me because I'm used to being asked so many questions at this time.  As a prisoner, I will say that I should put it clear that it wasn't my intention to start a fight or attack the ANC people, they are the people who attacked us.  And now if you continue asking me these questions I got confused when answering the questions.

Mr Zuma, the question you got confused about was the fourth question asked by your own attorney, it was not a lot of questions, it was your own attorney leading your evidence and right at the beginning of your evidence you said that you were attacked, you knew most of them, they said - called out -Vusi we are coming and that you them ran down the hill.  We're asking about that, not what you said after lot's of questioning but what you told your - your own attorney led you on this.

Yes, I said it like that however now I find myself in a confused state.  I knew the people we were fighting against.  Ntolo was from Ndaleni, that's why I'm saying now that I saw him at the Supreme Court, that he was there when we attacked them.
I presume that it was not too dark when an attack was launched in your stronghold and if ...(intervention)
Yes it was in the dark, it was somewhere around 4 or 3 in the afternoon, I didn't look at the  time.
And you are now saying - you are now changing your evidence to say you didn't recognise any of the persons who launched an attack against you on the 23rd of June.
I saw them coming to attack us however I didn't recognise them.

And in your evidence you actually painted quite a beautiful picture by saying you were in a strategic place, you were higher up and you could see what was going on from down there, you could vividly see the people who were coming up to attack you.
Now you obviously are saying you couldn't see anything and that piece of evidence we should disregard because it wasn't correct?
People whom I saw when they started attacking us starting from 1991, February, I used to see these people but those who attacked us on the 23rd of June, I didn't ...(intervention)
He's saying he didn't see them - I don't know what he means - he didn't recognise or see them.
I presume you must have consulted with your lawyer?
Yes, I just get confused - I don't know, I don't know what's happening.

Well Mr Zuma, I would say if you're having some problems you must have a glass of water, you must relax because whatever you are saying we are taking down.  It is an important part of your application, it is the application and it is an important requirement of your application for amnesty not to ...(inaudible) your evidence but to tell us exactly what happened.
	And no one is putting any pressure on you, no one is asking any questions, this is the evidence you gave as Judge Wilson has stated.  This is the evidence you gave when you were being led by your own attorney.  If you're not going to be comfortable with the leading of questions by your own attorney, I don't know how you can be made more comfortable than that.  I would say please try and relax and think about what you want us to take as your evidence.
Yes, I will come back to that point.
Thank you Ma'am.  In your evidence you testified that you were targeting ANC young men, do you remember that?
Now why did you kill three young boys?
It wasn't clear because it was at night.

No, but it comes from - it is your evidence, you said you saw three young boys and these three young boys were killed.  The word boys comes from you and you also gave evidence that your target was actually young men so it means if you could differentiate between boys and men you saw these people.

When I referred to a young child, I'm referring to anyone who is below ten years of age.  Above that I would say it's a grown up youth and since it was at night it was also difficult to distinguish between an adult and a child.
What you told us or told this Committee when you said you saw three young boys and you killed the three young boys, is not true?

I didn't say we kill young children, we found three of them in a rondawel, there were three.  We didn't, I didn't try to find out whether they were grown up or still young, we stabbed them and I went out and peeped through the window while the others were still stabbing.
Let us be careful Mr Zuma, you say in that house you found three young children, is that your evidence?
If I remember well I didn't say three young children, I said three people.
Three young children.  You are at liberty to change, are you changing?  You are liberty to do that.
Mr Mpshe, were any young boys killed?
Apart from the baby of three.
If my young ...(inaudible) below the age of twenty one.
Oh well that I wouldn't call young boys, I would call those youths, that's not a young boy.
Do you deny that you said you found three young children?
I would like to correct this.  I didn't say children, I couldn't kill young children even young boys, I said three people in the house which was a rondawel.
Were you armed on this day, the launching of the attack?
Yes, I was armed with three, two spears and two ...(inaudible).
Those were knopkierries with some ...(inaudible) on top of them.

Thank you Mr Chairperson, no further questions.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR MPSHE

Mr Zuma, in the light of your more recent version that you did not identify any of the attackers, can you explain to us why you decided to attack these particular people that victim to you and your group on the 23rd of June 1991.
May you please repeat the question for me?

Accepting your version that you did not identify any of the attackers, for what reason did you decide to attack these particular
people who fell victim to you and your group on the 23rd of June 1991?

It was because they shot at us, at our homes and they terrorized us.  They terrorized us and victimized us and I would say this is the reason why I got involved in attacking them as a way paying revenge because they shot ...(inaudible).  That's the reason why I joined in the attack.
Are you suggesting that you attacked these particular people because you were taking revenge for things that they have done prior to the 23rd of June 1991?
So your revenge had nothing to do with what happened in your area earlier on that  particular day?
I don't understand this question now, may you please repeat the question, I don't hear it very well.
